caption.p: Pharmacological activities of Parkia species extracts and fractions.

tr.td: Active against S. aureus, B. subtilis, E. coli, P. aeruginosa.
Active against E. coli, S. aureus, K. pneumoniae, P. aeruginosa. Activity: Aqueous > methanol
Active against S. aureus, E. aerogenes, S. typi, S. typhimurium, Shigella spp., E. coli, and P. aeruginosa (bacteria), Mucor spp., and Rhizopus spp. (fungi)
Active against E. coli, S. enterica, and S. dysenteriae. Activity: hydroalcoholic > aqueous
Active against S. aureus, A. hydrophila, S. agalactiae, S. anginosus, and V. parahaemolyticus isolated from moribund fishes and shrimps
EA: Four times higher than streptomycin against S. aureus and three times higher for E. coli. Hexane: 50% inhibitory ability of streptomycin for both bacteria. Ethanol: no inhibition
Pod: active against P. aeruginosa Silver particles: active against P. aeruginosa
Bark: Active against G. trabeum. Sapwood and heartwood: No effect
Chloroform, petroleum ether, Aqueous and methanol
Active against H. pylori except aqueous extract. Activity: chloroform > methanol > petroleum ether
Methanol: active against H. pylori. Ethyl acetate: active against E. coli Both: no effect on S. typhimurium, S. typhi, and S sonnei
Good inhibitory activity against E. coli, S. aureus S. pyogenes found in chronic wound
Active against four Vibrio cholerae strains
Good inhibitory activity against S. aureus
Methanol extract and semi-polar fractions (chloroform and ethyl acetate)
Active against Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Chloroform showed the best activity
Active against S. aureus, A . hydrophila, and S. typhimurium Not active against E. coli
Active against S. aureus and P. aeruginosa. Methanol extract was more potent
Active against E. coli, P. aeruginosa, and S. aureus
Active against S. aureus, K. pneumoniae, P. aeruginosa, S. viridans and B. subtilis. Not active against E. coli
Active against E. coli, S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, A. niger, B. cereus and a fungus, C. utilis
Active against C. diphtheria, K. pneumoniae, P. mirabilis, S. typhi, and S. pyogenes
Reduced cellular infectivity of human cytomegalovirus in human embryo lung (HEL) cells.
Strong glucose-lowering activity in alloxan-induced diabetic rats Activity: seeds > pod
Inhibited α-glucosidase activity in rat Activity: rind > leaf > seed
Reduced plasma glucose levels in alloxan-induced diabetic rats
Reduced fasting plasma glucose in alloxan-induced diabetic rats
Significantly increased lipid peroxidation product levels in brain and testes of diabetic rats
Showed glucose-lowering effect Activity: chloroform > methanol > n-hexane
Reduced blood glucose inhibited α-glucosidase and α-amylase in streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats
Increased apoptosis in sarcoma-180 cancer cell lines
Caused 50% death in HepG2 (liver cancer cell) but not cytotoxic to normal cells
Inhibited proliferation in cancerous cell lines; P388DI and J774, B-cell hybridoma and HB98 cell line
Demonstrated selective cytotoxicity to MCG-7 and T47D (breast cancer), HCT-116 (colon cancer)
Showed selective cytotoxicity on breast cancer cells MCF-7
Antiproliferative effect in human cancer cells T-549, BT-20, and PC-3
Antiproliferative effect in in human cancer cells T-549, BT-20, and PC-3
T cell mitogen and antiproliferative against P388DI and J774 cancer cell lines
Showed moderate ACE-inhibitory activity in in vitro
Inhibited angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) in rats. No effect observed in non-hydrolyzed samples
Prevented the increases in blood pressure and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) and restored nitric oxide in hypertensive rat model
Induced hypotension in adrenaline-induced hypertensive rabbits
Induced relaxation in rat aorta precontracted with phenylephrine in the presence or absence of endothelium.
Lower blood pressure, blood glucose, and heart rate, high level of magnesium as well as improved lipid profile in patients with hypertension
The extract of stem bark exhibit dose-dependent antidiarrheal activity at different concentrations in albino rats with castor oil-induced diarrhea
Reduced frequency of stooling in castor-oil induced diarrhea in rats
The extract exhibited 100% protections at 100 and 200 mg/kg bw in the diarrheal rats
Reduced frequency of stooling and improved transit time at 100 and 200 mg/kg bw
Reduced mucosal injury and increased in periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) staining induced by ethanol
Decreased gastric juice acidity, lesion length, collagen content and fibrosis in indomethacin-induced peptic ulcer in rats
Reduced gastric mucosal lesion induced by ethanol, ischemia-reperfusion and ethanol-HCl
Combination of fermented seed with other fermented products
Increased hemoglobin, red blood cell, white blood cell levels and packed cell volume in albino rats
Increased hemoglobin levels in NaNO 2-induced anemic mice
Increased hemoglobin levels in NaNO 2-induced anemic mice
The extract and the isolated compound showed antiangiogenic activity on the caudal fin of adult zebrafish
Inhibited more than 50% micro vessel outgrowth in rat aortae and HUVECs
Showed antiplasmodial activity caused by P. berghei and P. falciparum
Reduced serum creatinine, Na, urine proteins and leukocytes and kidney weight in gentamicin-induced renal damage in rats
Reduced serum alanine and aspartate transaminases, and alkaline phosphatase in paracetamol-induced hepatotoxicity rat model
Increased skin wound repair in immunosuppressed mice
Reduced iNOS activity, COX-2, VCAM-1 and NF-κB expressions in cardiomyocytes exposed to tumor necrosis factor-α
Reduced iNOS activity, COX-2, VCAM-1 and NF-κB expressions in HUVECs exposed to tumor necrosis factor-α
Inhibited croton pellet granuloma formation and carrageenin-induced rat paw edema
Lectin showed anti-inflammatory effect by inhibition of pro-inflammatory cytokine release and stimulation of anti-inflammatory cytokine release on peritonitis induced model mice
Reduced carrageenan- and PMA-induced edema in mice
Increased percentage protection of the human red blood cell membrane
Lectin showed antinociceptive effect in the mouse model of acetic acid-induced
Methanol extract showed the highest antioxidant potential activities (DPPH test) of about 85% and (FRAP test) of about 0.9 mM Fe (II)/g dry
All the extracts exhibited good antioxidant activity. The aqueous extract showed the highest values of 47.42 and 26.6 mg of ascorbic acid equivalent/g in DPPH and FRAP tests, respectively
High content of total phenolic and flavonoid. Showed high reducing power and strong radical scavenging activity.
Showed increased DPPH and ferric-reducing power activities concentration-dependently
Reduced NOX4, SOD1, p38 MAPK protein expressions and ROS level
Increased DPPH and ABTS scavenging activities, reduced lipid peroxidation Activity: ethanol > aqueous
Extract exhibited significant activity (DPPH and FRAP tests)
Reduced Heinz body formation in erythrocytes incubated with acetyl phenylhydrazine. Activity: seed coat > pods >
Fermented seed increased reduction of Fe 3+ to Fe 2+.
Mitigated ferric-induced lipid peroxidation in rat tissues and increased scavenging activities against DPPH and ABTS, ferric-reducing ability
Increased DPPH scavenging activity and reducing power.
Increased scavenging activity against DPPH free radical Activity: methanol > hydroethanolic

fn.p: Abbreviations: HUVECs, human umbilical vein endothelial cells; DPPH, 2,2-Diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazy; ABTS, 2,20-Azinobis (3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulphonic acid) diammonium salt; FRAP, ferric reducing antioxidant power; iNOS, inducible nitric oxide synthase; PMA, phorbol myristate acetate; COX-2, cyclooxygenase-2; VCAM-1, vascular cell adhesion moelcule-1; NF-κB, nuclear factor kappa-B; ACE, angiotensin converting enzyme; HEL, human embryo lung; PAS, periodic acid-Schiff; bw, body weight.
